title: spocc introduction
text: spocc currently interfaces seven major biodiversity repositories Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF) (via rgbif) GBIF government funded open data repository several partner organizations express goal providing access data Earth’s biodiversity. data made available network member nodes, coordinating information various participant organizations government agencies. iNaturalist iNaturalist provides access crowd sourced citizen science data species observations. VertNet (via rvertnet) Similar rgbif (see ), VertNet provides access 80 million vertebrate records spanning large number institutions museums primarly covering four major disciplines (mammology, herpetology, ornithology, icthyology). eBird (via rebird) ebird database developed maintained Cornell Lab Ornithology National Audubon Society. provides real-time access checklist data, data bird abundance distribution, communtiy reports birders. iDigBio (via ridigbio) iDigBio facilitates digitization biological paleobiological specimens associated data, houses specimen data, well providing specimen data via RESTful web services. OBIS OBIS (Ocean Biogeographic Information System) allows users search marine species datasets world’s oceans. Atlas Living Australia ALA (Atlas Living Australia) contains information known species Australia aggregated wide range data providers: museums, herbaria, community groups, government departments, individuals universities; contains 50 million occurrence records. Important Note: ’s important keep mind several data providers interface many mentioned repositories. means occurence data obtained OBIS may duplicates data also available GBIF. way resolve duplicates overlaps time issue hoping resolve future versions package. See ?spocc_duplicates, installation, .

title: spocc introduction
text: significant function spocc occ (short occurrence) function. occ takes query, often species name, searches across data sources specified argument. example, one can search occurrences Sharp-shinned Hawks (Accipiter striatus) GBIF database following R call. data returned part S3 class called occdat. class slots data sources described . One can easily switch source changing parameter function call . Within data source set species queried. example, asked occurrence data one species, asked number. Let’s say asked data two species: Accipiter striatus, Pinus contorta. structure response request data gbif, like = 'gbif', four source slots present response object, data. can quickly get just GBIF data indexing , like get data multiple providers, fields returned slightly different data provider uses different formats data; different arrangements data different variable names thing (e.g., one data provider may call latitude “latitude”, another may call “lat”). example: provide function occ2df pulls key columns needed making maps: occ2df() combines data single data.frame, also standardizes key columns (name, longitude, latitude, prov (provider), date, key (occurrence key)). Note can look exact occurrence data provider using key value.

title: spocc introduction
text: data source variety different ways, parameters, use search data. parameters across data sources. occ() ’ve attempted surface similar parameters can single way define parameter gets applied every data source. way don’t know vagaries data source, formatting expect, etc. standardized parameters occ() : query: scientific taxon name limit: number records retrieve start: page number start page: page number retrieve geometry: “spatial filter” - bounding box, well known text, sp sf polygon multipolygon has_coords: exclude records without latitude/longitude data date: date range However, parameters across data sources able standardized, can pass data source specific parameters matching parameter name, e.g., pass GBIF parameters gbifopts ALA parameters alaopts.

title: Coerce occurrence keys to gbifkey/occkey objects — as.gbif
code: if (FALSE) { spnames <- c('Accipiter striatus', 'Setophaga caerulescens',    'Spinus tristis') out <- occ(query=spnames, from=c('gbif','ebird'),    gbifopts=list(hasCoordinate=TRUE), limit=2) res <- occ2df(out) (tt <- as.gbif(out)) (uu <- as.gbif(res)) as.gbif(as.numeric(res$key[1])) as.gbif(res$key[1]) as.gbif(as.list(res$key[1:2])) as.gbif(tt[[1]]) as.gbif(uu[[1]]) as.gbif(tt[1:2]) }

title: Search for species occurrence data across many data sources. — occ
text: query (character) One many scientific names. See Details parameter data source query. Note: ebird now expects species codes instead scientific names - pass name rebird::species_code() internally (character) Data source get data , combination gbif, inat, ebird, vertnet, idigbio, obis, ala. See vignette(topic = 'spocc introduction') details sources. limit (numeric) Number records return. passed across sources. specify different limits source, use options source (gbifopts, inatopts, ebirdopts). See Details . Default: 500 source. BEWARE: lot species query (e.g., n = 10), 10 * 500 = 5000, can take collect. , first query, set limit something smallish can get result quickly, needed. start, page (integer) Record start page start . See Paging Details parameters used internally. Optional geometry (character nmeric) One Well Known Text (WKT) object, vector length 4 specifying bounding box, sf object (sfg, sfc, sf). parameter searches occurrences inside polygon - converted polygon whatever user input given. WKT shape written POLYGON((30.1 10.1, 20 40, 40 40, 30.1 10.1)) queried , .e. http://bit.ly/HwUSif. See Details examples WKT objects. format bounding box min-longitude, min-latitude, max-longitude, max-latitude. Geometry possible vertnet right now, soon. See Details info geometry inputs. has_coords (logical) return occurrences lat/long data. works gbif, rinat, idigbio, vertnet, ignored ebird. can easily though remove records without lat/long data. ids Taxonomic identifiers. can list length 1 many. See examples usage. Currently, identifiers 'gbif' parameter '' supported. parameter used, query parameter can used - , warning thrown. date (character/Date) length 2 vector containing two dates form YYY-MM-DD. can character Date class. used date range search. course types date searches one may want date range seems like common date search use case. callopts Options passed crul::HttpClient, e.g., debugging curl calls, setting timeouts, etc. gbifopts (list) List named options pass rgbif::occ_search(). See also occ_options() inatopts (list) List named options pass internal function get_inat_obs ebirdopts (list) List named options pass rebird::ebirdregion() rebird::ebirdgeo(). See also occ_options() vertnetopts (list) List named options pass rvertnet::searchbyterm(). See also occ_options(). idigbioopts (list) List named options pass ridigbio::idig_search_records(). See also occ_options(). obisopts (list) List named options pass internal function. See  https://api.obis.org/#/Occurrence/get_occurrence obis_search parameters can used. alaopts (list) List named options pass internal function. throw_warnings (logical) occ() collects errors returned data provider occur, accessible $meta$errors slot data provider. set throw_warnings=TRUE, give request errors warnings warning(). FALSE, give warnings, can still access output.

title: Search for species occurrence data across many data sources. — occ

title: Search for species occurrence data across many data sources. — occ
text: WKT objects strings pairs lat/long coordinates define shape. Many classes shapes supported, including POLYGON, POINT, MULTIPOLYGON. Within defined shape define vertices shape coordinate like 30.1 10.1, first latitude, second longitude. Examples valid WKT objects: 'POLYGON((30.1 10.1, 10 20, 20 60, 60 60, 30.1 10.1))' 'POINT((30.1 10.1))' 'LINESTRING(3 4,10 50,20 25)' 'MULTIPOINT((3.5 5.6),(4.8 10.5))")' 'MULTILINESTRING((3 4,10 50,20 25),(-5 -8,-10 -8,-15 -4))' 'MULTIPOLYGON(((1 1,5 1,5 5,1 5,1 1),(2 2,2 3,3 3,3 2,2 2)),((6 3,9 2,9 4,6 3)))' 'GEOMETRYCOLLECTION(POINT(4 6),LINESTRING(4 6,7 10))' POLYGON objects currently supported. Getting WKT polygons bounding boxes. soon introduce function help select bounding box now, can use sites web. Bounding box - https://boundingbox.klokantech.com/ Well known text - http://arthur-e.github.io/Wicket/sandbox-gmaps3.html

Default: 0 inat - Responds page. Default: 1 ebird - paging, start page ignored. vertnet - paging implemented , start page ignored. VertNet form paging, uses cursor, easily included  via parameters. However, rvertnet paging internally .  example, max records per request VertNet 1000; request 2000 records, first request, second request automatically. idigbio - Responds start. Default: 0 obis - respond start. allow starting occurrence UUID skip. order results matters great deal course. paginate OBIS, e.g. obisopts = list(= "017b7818-5b2c-4c88-9d76-f4471afe5584"); can combined limit value pass main occ() function call. title: Search for species occurrence data across many data sources. — occ
code: if (FALSE) { # Single data sources (res <- occ(query = 'Accipiter striatus', from = 'gbif', limit = 5)) res$gbif (res <- occ(query = 'Accipiter striatus', from = 'ebird', limit = 50)) res$ebird (res <- occ(query = 'Danaus plexippus', from = 'inat', limit = 50,   has_coords = TRUE)) res$inat res$inat$data data.table::rbindlist(res$inat$data$Danaus_plexippus$photos) (res <- occ(query = 'Bison bison', from = 'vertnet', limit = 5)) res$vertnet res$vertnet$data$Bison_bison occ2df(res)  # Paging one <- occ(query = 'Accipiter striatus', from = 'gbif', limit = 5) two <- occ(query = 'Accipiter striatus', from = 'gbif', limit = 5, start = 5) one$gbif two$gbif  # iNaturalist limits: they allow at most 10,000; query through GBIF to get # more than 10,000 # See https://www.gbif.org/dataset/50c9509d-22c7-4a22-a47d-8c48425ef4a7 # x <- occ(query = 'Danaus plexippus', from = 'gbif', limit = 10100,  #   gbifopts = list(datasetKey = "50c9509d-22c7-4a22-a47d-8c48425ef4a7")) # x$gbif  # Date range searches across data sources ## Not possible for ebird ## ala occ(date = c('2018-01-01T00:00:00Z', '2018-03-28T00:00:00Z'), from = 'ala', limit = 5) ## gbif occ(query = 'Accipiter striatus', date = c('2010-08-01', '2010-08-31'), from = 'gbif', limit=5) ## vertnet occ(query = 'Mustela nigripes', date = c('1990-01-01', '2015-12-31'), from = 'vertnet', limit=5) ## idigbio occ(query = 'Acer', date = c('2010-01-01', '2015-12-31'), from = 'idigbio', limit=5) ## obis occ(query = 'Mola mola', date = c('2015-01-01', '2015-12-31'), from = 'obis', limit=5) ## inat occ(query = 'Danaus plexippus', date = c('2015-01-01', '2015-12-31'), from = 'inat', limit=5)   # Restrict to records with coordinates occ(query = "Acer", from = "idigbio", limit = 5, has_coords = TRUE)  occ(query = 'Setophaga caerulescens', from = 'ebird', ebirdopts = list(loc='US')) occ(query = 'Spinus tristis', from = 'ebird', ebirdopts =    list(method = 'ebirdgeo', lat = 42, lng = -76, dist = 50))  # idigbio data ## scientific name search occ(query = "Acer", from = "idigbio", limit = 5) occ(query = "Acer", from = "idigbio", idigbioopts = list(offset = 5, limit  = 3)) ## geo search bounds <- c(-120, 40, -100, 45) occ(from = "idigbio", geometry = bounds, limit = 10) ## just class arachnida, spiders occ(idigbioopts = list(rq = list(class = 'arachnida')), from = "idigbio", limit = 10) ## search certain recordsets sets <- c("1ffce054-8e3e-4209-9ff4-c26fa6c24c2f",     "8dc14464-57b3-423e-8cb0-950ab8f36b6f",      "26f7cbde-fbcb-4500-80a9-a99daa0ead9d") occ(idigbioopts = list(rq = list(recordset = sets)), from = "idigbio", limit = 10)  # Many data sources (out <- occ(query = 'Pinus contorta', from=c('gbif','vertnet'), limit=10))  ## Select individual elements out$gbif out$gbif$data out$vertnet  ## Coerce to combined data.frame, selects minimal set of ## columns (name, lat, long, provider, date, occurrence key) occ2df(out)  # Pass in limit parameter to all sources. This limits the number of occurrences # returned to 10, in this example, for all sources, in this case gbif and inat. occ(query='Pinus contorta', from=c('gbif','inat'), limit=10)  # Geometry ## Pass in geometry parameter to all sources. This constraints the search to the ## specified polygon for all sources, gbif in this example. ## Check out http://arthur-e.github.io/Wicket/sandbox-gmaps3.html to get a WKT string occ(query='Accipiter', from='gbif',    geometry='POLYGON((30.1 10.1, 10 20, 20 60, 60 60, 30.1 10.1))')  ## Or pass in a bounding box, which is automatically converted to WKT (required by GBIF) ## via the bbox2wkt function. The format of a bounding box is ## [min-longitude, min-latitude, max-longitude, max-latitude]. occ(query='Accipiter striatus', from='gbif', geometry=c(-125.0,38.4,-121.8,40.9))  ## lots of results, can see how many by indexing to meta res <- occ(query='Accipiter striatus', from='gbif',    geometry='POLYGON((-69.9 49.2,-69.9 29.0,-123.3 29.0,-123.3 49.2,-69.9 49.2))') res$gbif  ## You can pass in geometry to each source separately via their opts parameter, at ## least those that support it. Note that if you use rinat, you reverse the order, with ## latitude first, and longitude second, but here it's the reverse for consistency across ## the spocc package bounds <- c(-125.0,38.4,-121.8,40.9) occ(query = 'Danaus plexippus', from="inat", geometry=bounds)  ## Passing geometry with multiple sources occ(query = 'Danaus plexippus', from=c("inat","gbif"), geometry=bounds)  ## Using geometry only for the query ### A single bounding box occ(geometry = bounds, from = "gbif", limit=50) ### Many bounding boxes occ(geometry = list(c(-125.0,38.4,-121.8,40.9), c(-115.0,22.4,-111.8,30.9)), from = "gbif")  ## Geometry only with WKT wkt <- 'POLYGON((-98.9 44.2,-89.1 36.6,-116.7 37.5,-102.5 39.6,-98.9 44.2))' occ(from = "gbif", geometry = wkt, limit = 10)  # Specify many data sources, another example ebirdopts = list(loc = 'US'); gbifopts  =  list(country = 'US') out <- occ(query = 'Setophaga caerulescens', from = c('gbif','inat','ebird'),     gbifopts = gbifopts, ebirdopts = ebirdopts, limit=20) occ2df(out)  # Pass in many species names, combine just data to a single data.frame, and # first six rows spnames <- c('Accipiter striatus', 'Setophaga caerulescens', 'Spinus tristis') (out <- occ(query = spnames, from = 'gbif', gbifopts = list(hasCoordinate = TRUE), limit=25)) df <- occ2df(out) head(df)  # no query, geometry, or ids passed ## many dataset keys to gbif dsets <- c("14f3151a-e95d-493c-a40d-d9938ef62954", "f934f8e2-32ca-46a7-b2f8-b032a4740454") occ(limit = 20, from = "gbif", gbifopts = list(datasetKey = dsets)) ## class name to idigbio occ(limit = 20, from = "idigbio", idigbioopts = list(rq = list(class = 'arachnida')))  # taxize integration ## You can pass in taxonomic identifiers library("taxize") (ids <- get_ids(c("Chironomus riparius","Pinus contorta"), db = c('itis','gbif'))) occ(ids = ids, from='gbif', limit=20)  (ids <- get_ids("Chironomus riparius", db = 'gbif')) occ(ids = ids, from='gbif', limit=20)  (ids <- get_gbifid("Chironomus riparius")) occ(ids = ids, from='gbif', limit=20)  ## sf classes library("sp") library("sf") one <- Polygon(cbind(c(91,90,90,91), c(30,30,32,30))) spone = Polygons(list(one), "s1") sppoly = SpatialPolygons(list(spone), as.integer(1))  ## single polygon in a sf class x <- st_as_sf(sppoly) out <- occ(geometry = x, limit=50) out$gbif$data mapr::map_leaflet(out)  ## single polygon in a sfc class x <- st_as_sf(sppoly) out <- occ(geometry = x[[1]], limit=50) out$gbif$data  ## single polygon in a sf POLYGON class x <- st_as_sf(sppoly) x <- unclass(x[[1]])[[1]] class(x) out <- occ(geometry = x, limit=50) out$gbif$data  ## two polygons in an sf class one <- Polygon(cbind(c(-121.0,-117.9,-121.0,-121.0), c(39.4, 37.1, 35.1, 39.4))) two <- Polygon(cbind(c(-123.0,-121.2,-122.3,-124.5,-123.5,-124.1,-123.0),                      c(44.8,42.9,41.9,42.6,43.3,44.3,44.8))) spone = Polygons(list(one), "s1") sptwo = Polygons(list(two), "s2") sppoly = SpatialPolygons(list(spone, sptwo), 1:2) sppoly_df <- SpatialPolygonsDataFrame(sppoly,     data.frame(a=c(1,2), b=c("a","b"), c=c(TRUE,FALSE),    row.names=row.names(sppoly))) x <- st_as_sf(sppoly_df) out <- occ(geometry = x, limit=50) out$gbif$data   # curl debugging occ(query = 'Accipiter striatus', from = 'gbif', limit=10,   callopts=list(verbose = TRUE)) occ(query = 'Accipiter striatus', from = 'inat',   callopts=list(verbose = TRUE)) occ(query = 'Mola mola', from = 'obis', limit = 200,   callopts = list(verbose = TRUE))  ########## More thorough data source specific examples # idigbio ## scientific name search res <- occ(query = "Acer", from = "idigbio", limit = 5) res$idigbio  ## geo search ### bounding box bounds <- c(-120, 40, -100, 45) occ(from = "idigbio", geometry = bounds, limit = 10) ### wkt # wkt <- 'POLYGON((-69.9 49.2,-69.9 29.0,-123.3 29.0,-123.3 49.2,-69.9 49.2))' wkt <- 'POLYGON((-98.9 44.2,-89.1 36.6,-116.7 37.5,-102.5 39.6,-98.9 44.2))' occ(from = "idigbio", geometry = wkt, limit = 10)  ## limit fields returned occ(query = "Acer", from = "idigbio", limit = 5,    idigbioopts = list(fields = "scientificname"))  ## offset and max_items occ(query = "Acer", from = "idigbio", limit = 5,    idigbioopts = list(offset = 10))  ## sort occ(query = "Acer", from = "idigbio", limit = 5,    idigbioopts = list(sort = TRUE))$idigbio occ(query = "Acer", from = "idigbio", limit = 5,    idigbioopts = list(sort = FALSE))$idigbio  ## more complex queries ### parameters passed to "rq", get combined with the name queried occ(query = "Acer", from = "idigbio", limit = 5,    idigbioopts = list(rq = list(basisofrecord="fossilspecimen")))$idigbio  #### NOTE: no support for multipolygons yet ## WKT's are more flexible than bounding box's. You can pass in a WKT with multiple ## polygons like so (you can use POLYGON or MULTIPOLYGON) when specifying more than one ## polygon. Note how each polygon is in it's own set of parentheses. # occ(query='Accipiter striatus', from='gbif', #    geometry='MULTIPOLYGON((30 10, 10 20, 20 60, 60 60, 30 10), #                           (30 10, 10 20, 20 60, 60 60, 30 10))')  # OBIS examples ## basic query (res <- occ(query = 'Mola mola', from = 'obis', limit = 200)) ## get to obis data res$obis ## get obis + gbif data (res <- occ(query = 'Mola mola', from = c('obis', 'gbif'), limit = 200)) res$gbif res$obis ## no match found (res <- occ(query = 'Linguimaera thomsonia', from = 'obis')) ## geometry query geometry <- "POLYGON((8.98 48.05,15.66 48.05,15.66 45.40,8.98 45.40,8.98 48.05))" (res <- occ(from = 'obis', geometry = geometry, limit = 50)) res$obis  ## Pass in spatial classes ## sp classes no longer supported  ## Paging (res1 <- occ(query = 'Mola mola', from = 'obis', limit = 10)) occ_ids <- res1$obis$data$Mola_mola$id (res2 <- occ(query = 'Mola mola', from = 'obis',   limit = 10, obisopts = list(after = occ_ids[length(occ_ids)]))) res1$obis res2$obis ## Pass in any parameters to obisopts as a list (res <- occ(query = 'Mola mola', from = 'obis',     obisopts = list(startdepth = 40, enddepth = 50))) min(res$obis$data$Mola_mola$minimumDepthInMeters, na.rm=TRUE) max(res$obis$data$Mola_mola$maximumDepthInMeters, na.rm=TRUE)   # ALA examples ## basic query (res <- occ(query = 'Alaba vibex', from = 'ala', limit = 200)) ## get to ala data res$ala occ2df(res)  # geometry search (x <- occ(query = "Macropus", from = 'ala',   geometry = "POLYGON((145 -37,150 -37,150 -30,145 -30,145 -37))")) x$ala occ2df(x) }

what: Interface to many species occurrence data sources — spocc-package
title: Interface to many species occurrence data sources — spocc-package
text: programmatic interface many species occurrence data sources, including GBIF, iNaturalist, Berkeley Ecoinformatics Engine, eBird, iDigBio, VertNet, OBIS, ALA. Includes functionality retrieving species occurrence data, combining data.

title: Interface to many species occurrence data sources — spocc-package
text: main function use occ() - single interface many species occurrence databases (see list). functions include: occ2df() - Combine results occ data.frame wkt_vis() - Visualize WKT strings (used define geometry based searches data sources) interactive map

what: A note about duplicate occurrence records — spocc_duplicates
title: A note about duplicate occurrence records — spocc_duplicates
text: BEWARE: spocc provides nice interface many data providers species occurrence data. However, cases request data GBIF addition data sources, duplicate records. GBIF , use ecology  analogy, top predator, pulls data lower nodes food chain. example, iNaturalist provides data GBIF, search occurrence records Pinus contorta iNaturalist GBIF, get, example, 20 records. think single R interface many occurrence record providers provide consistent way work occurrence data, making analyses vizualizations repeatable across providers. cleaning data, see packages scrubr (https://cran.r-project.org/package=scrubr) CoordinateCleaner (https://cran.r-project.org/package=CoordinateCleaner) get touch us concerns, ideas eliminating duplicates
